quoteFirst: On the 2nd January the 2/4th Battalion disembarked and marched to quarters at St Andrew's barracks, and the same day at
quoteLast: the 1/4th Battalion paraded for the last time at Ghain Tuffieha, marched to Valetta and embarked on the _Avon_. That afternoon the _Avon_, conveying in addition to the 1/4th Battalion the 1/3rd Londons, put to sea under sealed orders, which were subsequently found to be for Marseilles.
title: The War History of the 4th Battalion, the London Regiment (Royal Fusiliers), 1914-1919
author: Grimwade, F. Clive

quoteFirst: General Chaffee's brigade took up a position six or eight hundred yards from the fort on the eastern side of the village; Ludlow's brigade marched around on the western side, so as to seize the Caney-Santiago road and thus cut off the enemy's escape; while the brigade of General Miles closed in on the south. Capron's battery, from the summit of a hill a little more than a mile southeast of the fort, fired the first shot at
title: Campaigning in Cuba
author: Kennan, George, 1845-1924

quoteFirst: Colman, M.P., signed “Another Invincible.”  Southgate was returning from night duty at
quoteLast: , when he was accosted by Betts, who fired a revolver at him, the bullet passing between his left arm and the side of his body.  Betts then withdrew to his house in Northumberland Street, where he barricaded himself.
title:
Norfolk Annals, Vol. 2
A Chronological Record of Remarkable Events in the Nineteeth Century
author: Mackie, Charles, 1858?-1940

quoteFirst: Left our camp at
quoteLast: , and followed the creek up for half an hour, and then steered east to Sturt's Creek, which we reached at 9.5, the country being level, sandy, and covered with triodia and acacia in small patches; we then steered a southerly course down the creek till 11.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteFirst: The next day the brigade moved out at 4.30 a.m. to march on Shahroban with orders to skirt the town, the Buffs to go round the south side and the Dogras the north. The great objective was a certain nullah, and this was occupied without opposition at
quoteLast: Then another period of monotony set in and until the 18th October the battalion was at Shahroban in Mesopotamia, and that was all its history.
title: Historical records of the Buffs, East Kent Regiment (3rd Foot)
author: Moody, R. S. H. (Richard Stanley Hawks), 1854-1930; Alexander, Herbert, 1874-1946 [Artist]; Butler, Elizabeth (Elizabeth Southerden Thompson), 1846-1933 [Artist]; Paget, Arthur, 1851-1928 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: It was the first coin he found in his pocket, and the sight of it caused a frown. Confound those Montmartre playwrights! Why was their stupid travesty constantly recurring to his mind? He frowned again, this time at Auguste Comte's smugness, and looked at his watch.
quoteLast: ! It was too late now to do other than write--if he succeeded. If not--ah, well! "Some of them are slain in the flower of their youth.
title: A Son of the Immortals
author: Tracy, Louis, 1863-1928; Christy, Howard Chandler, 1873-1952 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Premising, however, that the shilling is properly suspended, you will observe, that when it has recovered its equilibrium, it will for a moment be stationary: it will then of its own accord, and without the least agency from the person holding it, assume the action of a pendulum, vibrating from side to side of the glass, and, after a few seconds, will strike the hour nearest to the time of day; for instance, if the time be twenty-five minutes past six, it will strike six; if
quoteLast: , it will strike seven; and so on of any other hour.
title:
Endless Amusement
A Collection of Nearly 400 Entertaining Experiments in Various Branches of Science; Including Acoustics, Electricity, Magnetism, Arithmetic, Hydraulics, Mechanics, Chemistry, Hydrostatics, Optics; Wonders of the Air-Pump; All the Popular Tricks and Changes of the Cards, &c., &c. to Which is Added, a Complete System of Pyrotechny; Or, the Art of Making Fire-works.
author: Unknown

quoteFirst: It was the first coin he found in his pocket, and the sight of it caused a frown. Confound those Montmartre playwrights! Why was their stupid travesty constantly recurring to his mind? He frowned again, this time at Auguste Comte's smugness, and looked at his watch.
quoteLast: ! It was too late now to do other than write--if he succeeded. If not--ah, well! "Some of them are slain in the flower of their youth.
title: A Son of the Immortals
author: Tracy, Louis, 1863-1928; Christy, Howard Chandler, 1873-1952 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: In about three minutes the smoke clearing away, we found ourselves abreast of the headmost ship, the sternmost ship luffing up for our larboard quarter; we poured a broadside into the headmost ship, and then braced aback our main and mizzen topsails, and backed astern under cover of the smoke, abreast the sternmost ship, when the action was continued with spirit and considerable effect until
quoteLast: , when the enemy's fire again slackened, and we discovered the headmost bearing up; filled our topsails, shot ahead, and gave her two stern rakes. We then discovered the sternmost ship wearing also; wore ship immediately after her, and gave her a stern rake, she luffing to on our starboard bow and giving us her larboard broadside.
title: The Medallic History of the United States of America 1776-1876
author: Loubat, J. F. (Joseph Florimond), 1831-1927; Jacquemart, Jules-Ferdinand, 1837-1880 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: _17th April, 1873._--A tremendous rain after dark burst all our now rotten tents to shreds. Went on at
quoteLast: for three hours, and I, who was suffering severely all night, had to rest. We got water near the surface by digging in yellow sand.
title:
The Last Journals of David Livingstone, in Central Africa, from 1865 to His Death, Volume II (of  2), 1869-1873
Continued By A Narrative Of His Last Moments And Sufferings, Obtained From His Faithful Servants Chuma And Susi
author: Livingstone, David, 1813-1873; Waller, Horace, 1833-1896 [Editor]

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: the enemy’s fire again slackened, and the headmost ship was discovered bearing up. Now the _Constitution_ reversed her tactics, shot ahead, crossed the first vessel’s stern and raked her fearfully, sailed about the stern most and raked her also; then, ranging up within hail on the larboard quarter, she prepared for another broadside, when the last ship fired a lee gun and remained silent.
title: Naval Actions of the War of 1812
author: Barnes, James, 1866-1936; Chapman, Carlton T., 1860-1925 [Illustrator]
